Answer: The limitation you're encountering is not due to the TelnetClient or DataOutputStream, but rather the Telnet protocol itself. The Telnet protocol has a maximum line length of 255 bytes, including the carriage return and line feed characters. This is a limitation of the protocol, not of the Java or TelnetClient libraries.

To overcome this limitation, you can break your command into smaller chunks and send them separately. Here's an example of how you can modify your write method to handle this:

```java
public String write(String command) {
    int maxLength = 255; // Maximum length of a line in Telnet protocol
    int numChunks = (int) Math.ceil((double) command.length() / maxLength);

    for (int i = 0; i < numChunks; i++) {
        int start = i * maxLength;
        int end = Math.min((i + 1) * maxLength, command.length());
        String chunk = command.substring(start, end) + "\n";
        byte[] comm = chunk.getBytes();
        out.write(comm);
        out.flush();
    }

    response = in.readLine();
    response = in.readLine();
    return response;
}
```

In this modified version of your write method, the command is divided into chunks of 255 bytes each, and each chunk is sent separately. The `\n` character is appended to each chunk to indicate the end of the command. The response is then read as before.

Please note that this solution assumes that the server will correctly handle the chunks and concatenate them back together. If this is not the case, you may need to modify your server-side code to handle this.
